intro: Paepalanthus leucoblepharus, commonly known as the white-eyed puya, is a flowering plant native to the Andean regions of South America. It belongs to the Bromeliaceae family and is characterized by its rosette-shaped leaves that form a central cup to collect water. The plant produces striking, showy inflorescences with brightly colored flowers, typically in shades of red, orange, or yellow. It thrives in high-altitude environments and is adapted to cool, humid climates. Due to its unique appearance and ecological significance, it is often cultivated in botanical gardens.
